awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  A Global View of Topographically Bound Low Level Jets
awd_abstract_narration:
Topographically bound low-level jets are strong, persistent winds in the lower atmosphere associated with elevated terrain features such as mountain ranges and plateaus.  Examples include the persistent northerly and southerly flows on opposite sides of the Rocky Mountains in North America and the Andes Mountains in South America, and the easterly flow that surrounds Antarctica. The goal of this project is to understand what causes these jets and to study their impacts on climate.  Previous work developed a two-dimensional theory which explains such jets as a balanced dynamical response of the atmosphere in response to forcing by solar heating and infrared radiative cooling of the elevated terrain.  Computed results using simplified terrain profiles showed qualitative agreement with observed winds in two-dimensional cross sections through the Andes and Antarctica.  

This project will extend the theory to three dimensions, taking into account the effects of the earth's spherical shape and the full shape of the elevated terrain.  Solutions of the resulting equations will be computed using a novel numerical method which refines the grid where needed to obtain accurate solutions with minimal computational work.  Solutions will be computed for jets associated with several regions of complex terrain around the globe, such as Antarctica, the Tibetan Plateau, Greenland, and the Rockies and Andes, and validated by comparison with observational data.

Beyond developing our fundamental understanding of atmospheric dynamics, this work has societal relevance due to the importance of low-level jets for regional climate. For example, the Great Plains low-level jet is responsible for a substantial portion of the moisture transport into the eastern half United States which sustains agriculture, and the low-level jet off the eastern coast of Africa is a major component of the Indian monsoon which greatly affects many aspects of life in the Indian subcontinent.  This project will also contribute to developing the future scientific workforce by supporting and training two graduate students in research, and training one undergraduate student in computational mathematics and modern scientific programming.  Finally, the methods developed in this project will be made available to researchers in atmospheric dynamics through software codes, so that they can be applied to a wide array of scientific problems.

por.por_cntn:
Topographically bound low-level jets are strong, persistent winds in the lower atmosphere associated with elevated terrain features such as mountain ranges and plateaus.  Examples include the persistent northerly and southerly flows on opposite sides of the Rocky Mountains in North America and the Andes Mountains in South America, and the easterly flow that surrounds Antarctica.

The primary goal of this project was to understand what causes these jets and to study their impacts on climate.  Previous work developed a two-dimensional theory which explains such jets as a balanced dynamical response of the atmosphere in response to forcing by solar heating and infrared radiative cooling of the elevated terrain.  Computed results using simplified terrain profiles showed qualitative agreement with observed winds in two-dimensional cross sections through the Andes and Antarctica.  

The primary effort in this collaborative project was to extend this work to three dimensions, developing a balanced model for low-level jets which takes into account the effects of the earth's spherical shape and the full shape of the elevated terrain.  While this work was not fully achieved (in part due to impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic), progress was made in several areas.  

First, we formulated a mathematical model of the two-dimensional circulation driven by radiative cooling and the associated katabatic (downslope) winds near the surface of Antarctica; this circulation in turn drives the balanced low-level jet described above. 

Second, we continued previous work to extend the new analytical approach introduced by A. S. Fokas.  This method did not live up to the promise suggested by its advocates:  while it does allow for solutions to simplified models, the simplifications required for the method to work are drastic enough to render it of little use in this context.

Third, we developed computer programs for solving these models.  Based on multigrid methods, these programs compute the solutions several orders of magnitude faster than single-grid methods commonly used for similar problems. Two-dimensional solvers were developed, and a three-dimensional solver (using hexagonal grids and local mesh refinement) was partially completed.  This solver is expected to be completed in future work.

This research had a broader impacts in both education and science.  The educational impact includes the involvement of a graduate student in the theoretical development and computer programming work of this project. The scientific inpact includes better understanding of the role of low-level jets in regional and global climate.
